subject: Re: Any tools for Test Case generation?
msgSnippet: Eclipse can help u out in a big way. Just configure the project in the eclipse and then right click on the class to test. Select new-- ... in it expand java in
messageBody:
Eclipse can help u out in a big way. Just configure the project in
the eclipse and then right click on the class to test. Select new--
>other from the dialog box which pops up.One more dialog box pops up,
in it expand java in the left pane, then u see junit. Check junit and
on the right pane select TestCase and then click next. Then u enter
the reqd info. and u get test case skeleton of the class.

Neeraj

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Ranjeet Sahay <rsahay@s...> wrote:
> JB misunderstood,
> Axis generates skeleton testcase, it is upto you to put asserts and
> values to test. Atleast it was useful in production environment
> where you donot have to write 1000 tests yourself .
> "Much like corporate make or buy decision."
>
>
> J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>
> >Ranjeet Sahay wrote:
> >
> >
> >>I would like to add there must be some tool to generate atleast
skeleton
> >>of testcases
> >>
> >>
> >
> >I have one: an Eclipse template. I type test, hit Ctrl+Space, and
get this
> >
> >public void test|() throws Exception {
> > fail("NYI");
> >}
> >
> >The | is the cursor, so I can type the test name. "NYI" means "not
yet
> >implemented," so the test fails until I explicitly say it's ready
to run.
> >
> >Beyond that I don't know what people would need.
> >
> >
> >
> >>To point Axis does generate JUnit TestCase skeleton for
WebService testing.
> >>
> >>
> >
> >This is the kind of thing I don't trust. *I* know what tests I
need to
> >write; Axis shouldn't be telling me.
> >
> >
>
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
